intro: Lychnis atropurpurea subsp. sartorii, commonly known as the purple poppy or Sartorii's campion, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring basal leaves that are often heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs. The plant produces striking clusters of pink to purple flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its flowers are five-petaled and have a distinctive, slightly spurred shape, typical of the Caryophyllaceae family. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, grasslands, and along roadsides.
